results.name: Triangular matrix T, read by rows, where row n of T equals row (n-1) of T^(n+1) with an appended '1'.
comment: Related to the number of subpartitions of a partition as defined in A115728; for examples involving column k of successive matrix powers, see A121430, A121431, A121432 and A121433. Essentially the same as triangle A101479, but this form best illustrates the nice properties of this triangle.
link: Alois P. Heinz, Rows n = 0..45, flattened
formula: G.f.: Column k of successive powers of T satisfy the amazing relation given by: 1 = Sum_{n>=0}(1-x)^(n+1)*x^(n(n+1)/2+k*n)*Sum_{j=0..n+k}[T^(j+1)](n+k,k)*x^j.
example: To get row 4 of T, append '1' to row 3 of matrix power T^5:
To get row 5 of T, append '1' to row 4 of matrix power T^6:
Likewise, get row n of T by appending '1' to row (n-1) of T^(n+1).
mathematica: Table[T[n, k], {n, 0, 9}, {k, 0, n}] // Flatten (* _Jean-François Alcover_, Oct 03 2019 *)
program: (PARI) {T(n, k)=local(A=Mat(1), B); for(m=1, n+1, B=matrix(m, m); for(i=1, m, for(j=1, i, if(j==i, B[i, j]=1, B[i, j]=(A^i)[i-1, j]); )); A=B); return((A^1)[n+1, k+1])}
